Join Friday nights intermediate/advanced players for some seriously fun, face-paced soccer under the lights at Hofstra University.   These games will be played on beautiful turf fields and are indoor/outdoor, depending on the season.  

Summer= Outside

Fall/Winter= Indoor

These games start promptly at 10:30 pm, please be on time or your spot may be given away to the walk-ons that do show up. 

The fee for this game is $15.00 which covers the cost of the field which you must pay even if you no show.  The field is expensive and the Club goes out of pocket for you if you do not show up! 

RSVP Rules apply!  Update cut off is 4:00 pm Friday.

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Can you think of a better idea than a day hike on Saturday the weekend after the turkey feast day? Let's do it! We will hike around Schunemunk Mountain, just about 60 miles north of New York.

The Schunemunk Mountain loop (the longest way) is an 11 mile hike with a good 1,500' of elevation gain. We will visit the summit of Schunemunk and the Megaliths, where we'll have near 360 degree views of the Highlands, Hudson River, Kittatinny Ridge, Shawangunks and the Catskills. From the summit we will head back down either by the Jessup and Trestle trail or via the Dark Hollow trail/Sweet Clover trail.

This is a strenuous hike (1,360'+ vertical rise, some rocky terrain and scrambling). Take with you a lunch snack and 1.5 liters of water. Be prepared for late fall weather, possibly rain or snow, wind and cold. Good boots are a must since ground could be wet. Other gear questions will be answered individually via e-mail.

We should be leaving New York City in cars around 8 a.m. on Saturday, November 28, and arriving back to NYC around 7 p.m. We may stop for dinner on the way back if there is interest.

The number of participants is limited only by the number of available cars. Sign up on the waiting list and I'll increase the number of participants as we get another driver(s) signed up.

Milos
results.name: Schunemunk Mountain Day Hike

results.description:
Join us at 8am for a run to Hoboken Pier A and back.
http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/121375029

Yes, there is a waterfront route to Hoboken. Enjoy the fun of cruising around Hoboken Pier A; around the new park and children playground at Newport where you will feel if you are at the beach. Get inspired by the man made majestic views of Manhattan!

The mapped distance is approx. 5.88 miles. You may run less or more in that time. We turn back after running 30 min to be back at 9 am. Hyatt pier is .31 miles so a double loop gets some runners 6.5 miles on this run.

9 am we run to Liberty State Park, a favorite place to run for most of us. Run on!

results.description:
When people hear about meditation, they almost always say that they have either never tried it or they were not able to do it. You may have expected that thoughts were supposed to go away, but when you closed your eyes, more thoughts than ever came up.

We invite you to come and experience how meditation can happen effortlessly with a little attention to our very own breath! The free session will include light yoga, breathing techniques and relaxing meditation and will be led by one of the volunteers of the Art of Living foundation.

 

Art of Living Secaucus Center

results.description:
Weather permitting, come join us for outdoor tennis at Washington Park in Union City, which is off of the 9th Street light rail station. Bring your sweats, your racquet, plenty of water and balls and we'll see you there! As this event is not designed to match up folks, courts are assigned on first-come first-served basis. So get in early and grab a court.


Make sure you only use 3-4 of the same numbered balls. Public courts do not allow use of more than 6 balls per court.

Also please try to use the same age balls as it will help you improve your game.

You can find each other in the waiting area and/or looking on the courts. It would help if you make a mental note of the profile picture of those attending.

Although we won't enforce attendance, it would be polite to attend if you commit because others are looking to find others to hit with.

Cross your fingers that it won't rain as inclement weather cancels the event.

If you have any questions, feel free to email the organizer.

results.description:
Details:

1 game (7 v 7) : Two halves of 30 minutes each with a break in between

-Please bring a fun and chill attitude. Absolutely no rough playing, slide-tackling or berating others; You’ll be asked to leave.

-Turf, AG cleats, or sneakers - no wet ground monster spikes.

-$4.00 goes for maintaining the website, equipment, and organization.

Rules:

This is a chill game so please bring a chill attitude; no meatheads or a$$holes. Organizers have the final say (i.e. if a ball is out of bounds we call it). 
It’s a small pitch so no corners kicks; just throwins.

Directions:

How to get to Brooklyn Bridge Park PIER 2 Sports Field:

To get past the BQE, you must enter Brooklyn Bridge Park on foot either fromm the south (at Joralemon St. & Furman St.) or the north (at Old Fulton St. & Furman St.)  Pier 2 is roughly halfway between these two entrances.  We play on the artificial grass field at the far end of the pier, behind the basketball courts & roller rink.

Google these coordinates:[masked], [masked]

Brooklyn Bridge Park is accessible by several subway lines (A/C, 2/3, 4/5, F, R) and bus routes (B25, B63)

Cancellation:

We'll play rain or shine.  We'll only cancel if there are fewer than 10 people going, or if there's lightning in the area.

results.description:
For this Healthy Neighborhoods Mobile Market volunteer effort in Harlem, please also register through the City Harvest website. Use the following link to register:


https://cityharvestvolunteers.civicore.com/index.php?section=indGpRegistrations&action=profile_conditional&fwID=3976


The Registration process is as follows:


• Follow the Group Sign-up Link above and click "New User" to create a new volunteer profile and click "Submit" (repeat or previously registered volunteers can simply log in)

• Read project details and click "Register" to confirm participation

• You will then receive a confirmation email and a reminder the day before the project


Only 10 volunteers are needed. All volunteers must be 18 years and older.

Description of Duties:

Volunteers will be stationed at 3-4 market tables, each supplied with thousands of pounds of fresh produce that they will help distribute to eligible market-goers. Sample produce items may include bananas, onions, cabbage, or potatoes. As the market-goers stop by each table, volunteers greet them-and then weigh and bag the produce. Note: All food is distributed free of charge.


That's it for now. If you have any questions, feel free to give me (Daniel) a call or text at [masked]. Thanks!

About City Harvest Healthy Neighborhoods Program


Nearly 1.4 million New Yorkers are facing hunger and for many people that City Harvest serves, healthy food is unavailable and unaffordable. In turn, diseases related to poor nutrition – including diabetes and heart disease – tend to be concentrated where demand for emergency food is greatest.

As a natural extension of the anti-hunger work we began more than 30 years ago, City Harvest developed Healthy Neighborhoods programs to respond to the need for emergency food, improve access to fruits and vegetables for residents in low-income communities and provide nutrition education that will inspire affordable, healthy meal choices. Through our Healthy Neighborhoods programs, City Harvest partners with residents, community organizations, afterschool programs, and local businesses. Together we work to achieve a long-term impact in the fight against hunger by engaging residents in healthy choices and enhancing the local food landscape. Building off our nutrition education classes which began in 2000, and our Mobile Markets which began in 2004, City Harvest has since expanded Healthy Neighborhoodsprograms to high-need communities across the five boroughs.

We will meet at the West 72nd street entrance to the park (W72nd and Central Park West) and run for about 50-60 minutes (roughly one full loop around the park). Then we'll head for some food/coffee.

Runners of all abilities are welcome, we will try to split people into groups of similar pace and we always wait for people at the finish.

results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. (If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.) From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a>  <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

• If you missed RSVP deadline, and know our starting point, feel free to join us on the day – just this one time :)

COME JOIN US FOR A FAST PACED INTERMEDIATE HIKE AS WE EXPLORE 4 PEAKS IN THE CENTRAL REGION OF THE CATSKILLS INCLUDING BALSAM, EAGLE, BIG INDIAN AND MAYBE FIR? THIS HIKE WILL INCLUDE SOME BUSHWHACKING AND IS NOT BEING OFFERED AS A BEGINNER HIKE! YOU CAN EXPECT THIS TRIP TO BE ABOUT 12-14 MILES. WHETHER OR NOT WE INCLUDE FIR WILL DEPEND ON THE WEATHER AND HOW WE FEEL THAT DAY.

http://www.catskillmountaineer.com/BIW-balsam.html

http://www.catskillmountaineer.com/BIW-eagle.html

http://www.catskillmountaineer.com/BIW-bigindian.html

http://www.catskillmountaineer.com/BIW-fir.html


WE WILL MEET AT the Biscuit Brook Trailhead Parking Area to spot cars (approx 2269 Co Rd 47, Claryville, NY)

WE WILL THEN PROCEED TO OUR START POINT AT the McKinley Hollow Trailhead Parking Area (approx 204 McKinley Hollow Rd, Big Indian, NY)


DISTANCE: Approximately 12-14 miles

HIKING PACE: up to 2 mph


ESTIMATED HIKE TIME: up to 9 hours

DIFFICULTY: Intermediate with some bushwhacking


CURRENT WEATHER FORECAST: Cloudy with a high of 42 degrees


RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Headlamp with spare batteries

• Shoes with good grip - preferably with ankle support


• A Medium Pack


• Related maps, a Compass or GPS, Enough Water for entire day, Snacks, First Aid, etc.

• Windbreaker, warm layers, hat, gloves, etc.

• Gaiters


• Hiking Poles




RELATED MAPS:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Catskills Trails Map Set

Catskill Hiking maximum group size limitations.

• A group size limit of 12 people for day hiking off-trail or in wilderness areas is in place. Any group larger than 12 must split up (by no less than 1 mile) into smaller, self-sufficient groups that satisfy the size requirement. These groups shall not congregate into one large group at trail junctions, rest stops, lunch breaks, etc.

• In all other areas of the Catskills a group size limit of 20 is in place. Groups larger than 20 must split up (by no less than 1 mile) into smaller, self-sufficient groups that satisfy the size requirement. These groups shall not congregate into one large group at trail junctions, rest stops, lunch breaks, etc.

results.description:
The Arts of Japan Galleries have been transformed into a dazzling fashion show of kimono from the late eighteenth century to the present day. Translated literally as “thing to wear,” the kimono has gone through major transformations throughout history: in the Edo period (1615–1868) it was an everyday garment, and now it is worn mainly on special occasions and collected as “traditional Japanese art.” Its design, function, and meaning have shifted dramatically in the last one hundred and fifty years, shaped by the dialogue of Japanese traditions, modern inventions, and Western ideas. Featuring more than fifty spectacular robes, this exhibition tells a story about the Japanese garment whose designs mirror trends in pictorial and decorative arts of every era. Both sumptuous garments custom-made for wealthy patrons and everyday wear available for sale to the general public are represented. Highlights also include three examples of contemporary kimono created by designers designated by the Japanese government as Living National Treasures.

Some twenty-five robes on loan from private and public collections, including the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, the John C. Weber Collection, Julia Meech Collection, and others complement examples from the Metropolitan’s Asian Art and Costume Institute collections; they are exhibited together with paintings, prints, and illustrated books, as well as lacquerware and ceramics, that share common design patterns with kimono. These T-shaped robes, decorated with a seemingly infinite variety of designs, not only reflect fashion trends but reveal much about Japanese culture, history, and society if we unlock the circumstances of their manufacture, sale, and ownership.

results.description:
Hey Outdoor Afros!

We hope you and your families will join us for a special visit to New York City’s National Monument.

We will spend the morning learning about and discussing African and African American history and connections to. This event is perfect for Outdoor Afros of all ages.


About the Monument

From about the 1690s until 1794, both free and enslaved Africans were buried in a 6.6-acre burial ground in Lower Manhattan, outside the boundaries of the settlement of New Amsterdam, later known as New York. Lost to history due to landfill and development, the grounds were rediscovered in 1991 as a consequence of the planned construction of a Federal office building.


About Outdoor Afro’s #HealthyHolidays Campaign

Throughout the country, Outdoor Afro is hosting events aimed at being intentional about Black family health. Whether you’re headed out of town for the holidays or hosting family, we have ideas and events for you and your family to enjoy. For more information visit: http://www.outdoorafro.com/2015/10/healthy-holidays-incorporating-the-outdoors-in-our-seasonal-celebrations/


What to Bring
Your Friends and Family
Water
Comfortable shoes
Warm jacket, scarf, hat (Weather permitting, we will visit some
historical locations outside)


Transportation
The Burial Ground is easily accessed from the following train stops:
Chambers Street (J,Z)
Brooklyn Bridge City Hall (4,5,6)
City Hall R


Release
Please be sure to bring a SIGNED copy of our release.

http://files.meetup.com/2045381/REQUIRED%20Outdoor%20Afro%20Trip%20Waiver.pdf


Hope to see you there!

Mahlon Dickerson was named after a former New Jersey governor and United States senator, it is the largest park of the Morris County Park System. This loop hike follows the Highlands Trail across several scenic streams and climbs to two panoramic viewpoints. Hike to Headley Overlook for a view of Lake Hopatcong, pass the highest point in Morris County (1395′), and return via the Ogden Mine Railroad rail bed. The first half on the Highlands trail was more rugged than the 2nd half on the Pine Swamp trail. One very minor scramble on Highlands Trail. Ogden Mine Railroad is flat, level, cinder path.

results.description:
Windham is unique in that it is not just the Northern most peak of the Catskill 35's but also the one with such contrasting views from north to south.  We will travel on high and overlook the hilltowns and then across Burnt Knob and Acra Point then towards the Blackhead range.  No other Catskill peak offers this contrast and variance of terrain &  No other trail in the Catskills is more scenic then the Escarpment trail.  

***  Winter conditions expected, traction device such as microspikes are highly recommended.  ***

*** Wear bright colors suggested, hunting season in the Cat's. ***

While I usually do this as a out and back, it's time to set up a short car shuttle and do Windham from one end to the other, across the ridge, lets find out what is on the other side.  The bear went over the mountain to see what he can see.

The hike will take us up about 1800 feet in 10 miles and along the way to the Catskill high peak of Windham Mountain, then on to Acra Point on a scenic ridgerun on the aptly named Escarpment Trail - IMHO the most beautiful of the Catskill trails. 8 star view points along the way.

Please post below for ride sharing, or view it if you an assist others who needs a ride.  Thanks

Children Welcome: Always (if they are capable), drop me a message and I will put your child in as your guest if guest function is disabled (Adults need to RSVP directly).  This does not not mean that this is a children's level hike, it does mean that some children are capable and ready for this hike.

Guests: Guest function, if enabled for this hike, is only for children (and teens who have not reached the age of majority).  Adults need to sign up directly and may not go as guests.  Children should be RSVP'ed as a guest their parent, guardian or responsible adult (which BTW would be their guardian).

No Shows/ short notice canceling/waitlisted:  Known 'No shows' may be waitlisted, and / or excluded from the event if there is a max number of hikers set.    Repeat short notice canceling will also be noted for consideration for this.   No-showing / short notice canceling prevents others from attending if the event is full.    Make sure you sign in, you would not want to be accidentally marked as a no-show, additionally frequently a few spots are reserved for those who are known to attend and be on time. 

Arriving Late: Don't do that, you may be on your own.  If you are late, we can only wait if it would be advantageous for the group to wait, so don't be late.   We will try to get you back on track, but those mornings are very hectic and my first responsibility would need to be to those hikers that have arrived.  You may not get to hike with us, additionally we may not have room to get you back to your vehicle at the end if that is required.

End of Hike Time: Ignore the Meetup end time, that is my suggestion for every meetup you attend, not just mine,  that is unless you know the event host uses that.  The reason is that Meetup assumes a end time and if the event organizer does not change it it just gives out a standard one.  Hikes normally move at 2mph so if the millage is specified one can easily figure out a rough estimate.  Larger groups sometimes move slower.

Dogs: I request No Dogs

Recommended Smartphone apps to assist meeting up:

Waze for driving, finding the group at a road side location.

Glympse: For driving and hiking, finding the group.

Having these free 2 apps preinstalled can greatly assist me in sending you my location (if needed).  Additionally I may send you the location via Apple's send location IM feature.

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. 

See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. 

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear. 

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. 
Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

results.description:
Calling all Fashionistas. The highly acclaimed Museum at FIT (Fashion Institute of Technology) has free exhibits.  Let's spend a Saturday morning learning more about the world of fashion.  Optional lunch and shopping trip to Macy's afterward with 12-15 Meetup friends in town from Washington, DC.

About the MuseumThe Museum at FIT, accredited by the American Alliance of Museums, is one of a select group of specialized fashion museums, including the Muse de la Mode, the Mode Museum, and the Museo de la Moda. For the 100,000 people who visit The Museum at FIT each year, we work to create exhibitions, programs, and publications that are both entertaining and educational. The mission of the Museum is to advance knowledge of fashion through exhibitions, programs and publications. Founded in 1969, the Museum was installed in the current building in 1974, and exhibitions began to be presented in 1975.  Dr. Valerie Steele has been director of The Museum at FIT since 2003 and chief curator since 1997. 

The Museum at FIT (MFIT) is best known for its innovative and award winning special exhibitions, including London Fashion, which received the first Richard Martin Award for Excellence in the Exhibition of Costume from the Costume Society of America; The Corset: Fashioning the Body , which explored the most controversial garment in the history of fashion; and Madame Grs: The Sphinx of Fashion , a monographic retrospective that examined the working methodologies and unique aesthetic contributions of a great couturier. Recently, the Museum has been mounting even more ambitious exhibitions, such as Gothic: Dark Glamour  and A Queer History of Fashion: From the Closet to the Catwalk.


The museums permanent collection encompasses some 50,000 garments and accessories from the 18th century to the present. Important designers such as Adrian, Balenciaga, Chanel, and Dior are represented. The collecting policy of the museum focuses on aesthetically and historically significant directional clothing, accessories, textiles and visual materials, with emphasis on contemporary avant-garde fashion. 

There are three galleries in the museum. The lower level gallery is devoted to special exhibitions, such as the recent Elegance in an Age of Crisis: Fashions of the 1930s and Dance and Fashion. The Fashion and Textile History Gallery, on the main floor, which provides on-going historical context, presents a rotating selection of approximately 200 historically and artistically significant objects from the museums permanent collection. Every six months, the exhibition in the gallery is completely changed, although it always covers 250 years of fashion history. 

Gallery FIT, also located on the main floor, is dedicated to student and faculty exhibitions, such as the Art and Design Graduating Student Exhibition every May, which also fills the lower level gallery and lobbies across campus. Students from FIT's School of Graduate Studies also collaborate with the Museum's staff to mount a professional museum exhibition once a year. 

We invite you to gain an intriguing perspective on the culture of fashion through the museum's engaging programs and publications. Our educational programming, Fashion Culture, includes free lectures, panel discussions, fashion conversations, and guided tours. The museums most ambitious program, the annual Fashion Symposium, features noted scholars, authors, and curators from around the world. 

In addition to its three exhibition galleries, the museum is composed of a conservation laboratory, photographic studio, workshop, more than 14,000 square feet of on-site storage space, three classrooms, and offices for 30 full-time employees. Members of the staff of The Museum at FIT have specialized skills in the conservation, documentation, exhibition, and interpretation of fashion.

The Fashion Institute of Technology, generally known as FIT, is a State University of New York (SUNY) college of art, business,design, mass communication and technology connected to the fashion industry, with an urban campus located on West 27th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, New York City.

It was founded in 1944, accredited in 1957, and is ranked among the top five fashion schools in the world. It has an enrollment of more than 10,000 students.

Thanks!

Robert Kelleman

[masked]

results.description: In a state of meditation, we are fully aware and connected to life, but we are also able to "step back" and look at ourselves and what's happening in our lives. In that state of detachment. we have the choice to stay stuck to what looks like a problem, or let go. When we let go, we can then see how the problem solves itself. We enjoy a state of peace, free of the obsessing, agonizing, and worrying. It sounds incredible, but that's how Sahaja Yoga works. Not when we "believe" it or conceptualize it, but when we do it; when we take five minutes every day to practice the meditation. Come and learn how to do it! (Sahaja Yoga meditation is always free.)

results.description:
Established in 1987, after lengthy grassroots efforts to preserve the area from development, the Pyramid Mountain Natural Historic Area is more than 1,500 acres of open space rich in natural and historical resources. Visitors to the park enjoy its environmental, natural, geological, and historical diversity.

Easily visible to hikers are the unusual geological attributes of Pyramid Mountain, such as Tripod Rock, a 160-ton boulder balanced atop three smaller rocks, known as a glacial erratic. The broad mountains, flat-topped ridges, and narrow valleys of Pyramid Mountain are not only beautiful, but also vital in feeding downstream reservoirs, supplying needed aquifers, and supporting flora and fauna.

The wide variety of natural habitats found within Pyramid Mountain include fields, forests, streams and ponds, which support a number of plants considered uncommon to New Jersey as well as threatened and endangered plants and animals. Historically, Pyramid Mountain is important for its lessons about the Lenape Indians, who flourished in this area, and the early European settlers, who came to the area to take advantage of its rich natural resources.

We are looking at a 3 hour hike with stops. We will have food after the hike at a local diner

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.

WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...

1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated

9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved

Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.


WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Okay guys, I was talking to some folks yesterday, and I mentioned I would be posting a hike at Ramapo for next week, but I forgot that holiday get-togethers are starting up, so let's shoot for the Saturday after Thanksgiving.  I can't give a full description of this hike since I couldn't find it on any of the sites, but we'll be doing a variation of this one:

http://www.njhiking.com/nj-hikes-ramapo-valley-county/


The start will be the same, but at the 1.8 mile mark, we'll actually be taking that left up the blue and take blue-white back down.  This will be about 5.5 miles total, or we may opt to do the one on the site that's a bit longer, but a more gradual climb, and more scenic.  I'll have to see what the consensus is.

Afterwards, we'll probably stop off at the Mason Jar or Mahwah Bar and Grill.  Looking forward to seeing you guys!
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be by the trailhead closest to the bathrooms at 11:15

results.description:
Tosca.

Approximate running time 3 hrs. 10 min.

Puccini’s timeless verismo score is well served by two exceptional casts. 

Conductor: Joseph Colaneri 

Tosca: Liudmyla Monastyrska
Cavaradossi: Roberto Aronica
Scarpia: Marco Vratogna
Sacristan: John Del Carlo
Production Team
Production: Luc Bondy
Set Designer: Richard Peduzzi
Costume Designer: Milena Canonero
Lighting Designer: Max Keller

Synopsis

Act I 


Rome, June 1800. Cesare Angelotti, an escaped political prisoner, rushes into the church of Sant’Andrea della Valle to hide in one of the chapels. Once he has disappeared, a sacristan enters and then the painter Mario Cavaradossi, who sets to work on his portrait of Mary Magdalene. The painting has been inspired by the Marchesa Attavanti, whom Cavaradossi has seen in the church but does not know. While he works, he compares the dark-haired beauty of his lover, the singer Floria Tosca, to that of the blonde Marchesa Attavanti (“Recondita armonia”). Angelotti, a member of the former Bonapartiste government, ventures out and is recognized by Cavaradossi. 

The painter gives him food and hurries him back into the chapel as Tosca is heard calling from outside. Suspicious, she jealously questions Cavaradossi, then reminds him of their rendezvous that evening at his villa. Suddenly recognizing the Marchesa Attavanti in the painting, she accuses him of being unfaithful, but he assures her of his love. When Tosca has left, Angelotti emerges from the chapel. A cannon signals that the police have discovered the escape, and he and Cavaradossi flee to the painter’s villa. The sacristan enters with choirboys who are preparing to sing in a Te Deum that day celebrating a victory against Napoleon. Their excitement is silenced by the arrival of Baron Scarpia, chief of the secret police, who is searching for Angelotti. When Tosca comes back looking for Cavaradossi, Scarpia shows her a fan with the Attavanti crest that he has just found. Seemingly finding her suspicions confirmed, Tosca bursts into tears. She vows vengeance and leaves as the church fills with worshipers. Scarpia sends his men to follow her to Cavaradossi’s villa, where he thinks Angelotti is hiding (“Tre sbirri... Una carozza...”). While the congregation sings the Te Deum, Scarpia declares that he will bend Tosca to his will.

Act II 

  In his study at the Palazzo Farnese, Scarpia sadistically anticipates the pleasure of having Tosca in his power (“Ha più forte sapore”). The spy Spoletta arrives, explaining that he was unable to find Angelotti. Instead he brings in Cavaradossi. While Scarpia interrogates the painter, Tosca is heard singing at a royal gala in the same building. Scarpia sends for her and she enters just as Cavaradossi is being taken away to be tortured. Frightened by Scarpia’s questions and Cavaradossi’s screams, Tosca reveals Angelotti’s hiding place. Cavaradossi is carried in, hurt and dazed. Realizing what has happened, he angrily confronts Tosca, when the officer Sciarrone rushes in to announce that, in a surprise, Napoleon has won the Battle of Marengo, a defeat for Scarpia’s side. Cavaradossi shouts out his defiance of tyranny and is dragged off to be executed. Scarpia, calmly resuming his supper, suggests to Tosca that he would let Cavaradossi go free if she’d give herself to him. Fighting off his advances, she calls on God, declaring that she has dedicated her life to art and love (“Vissi d’arte”). Scarpia insists, when Spoletta interrupts: faced with capture, Angelotti has killed himself. Tosca, now forced to give in or lose her lover, agrees to Scarpia’s proposition. The baron seemingly orders a mock execution for Cavaradossi, after which he is to be freed. Spoletta leaves. As soon as Scarpia has written a safe-conduct for the lovers, Tosca kills him with a knife she had found earlier on the table. Wrenching the document from his hand, she quietly leaves the room.

Act III
At dawn, Cavaradossi awaits execution at the Castel Sant’Angelo. He bribes the jailer to deliver a farewell letter to Tosca. Overcome with memories of love, he gives in to his despair (“E lucevan le stelle”). Tosca enters. She explains to him what has happened and the two imagine their future in freedom. As the firing squad appears, Tosca instructs Cavaradossi how to fake his death convincingly, then hides. The soldiers fire and depart. Tosca urges Cavaradossi to hurry, but when he doesn’t move, she realizes that Scarpia has betrayed her and that the bullets were real. Spoletta rushes in to arrest Tosca for murder. She cries out to Scarpia and leaps from the battlement.

Tickets

Please visit metopera.org.  Click on calendar.  Select November 28's date.  Select the Tosca evening performance.  Then, select your seat of choice. 


Meeting Details

At 12:00 pm We will meet in the lobby in front of the opera gift shop.  We will also meet at intermission on the lower level (below the orchestra) lounge for drinks or tea. There are high tops there and it is less frequented so it will be comfortable for making conversation between acts. 

See you soon!
results.name: Tosca! At the Metropolitan Opera

results.description:
course on a

If you are an international artists or creative professional wanting to work in the US, this Meetup is for you. This Meetup is intended for international creative professional looking to work in the US as freelancers.

CONTEMPORARY ART PRACTICE is an organization that develops tools and resources to support artists and creative professionals develop strong and successful careers.

This Meetup is structure to be a free 1 hour online info session followed by a 2 hours course.

During the info session you will learn:

1. What is an O1 visa? (also known as "Artist Visa")

2. Who is eligible for an O1 visa

3. What documents you need to apply

4. How much does it cost

5. How long does it take to put together

6. How can you build a good case for your application

If after the info session you decide you want to know more, you can stay for our following 2 hour course. We will cover:

1. How to find a sponsor

2. How to reach for recommenders

3. How to write letters of recommendation to fit USCIS requirements

4. How to organize your evidences and build categories

5. How to know if you need a consultation letter from the union related to your field

6. How to find employers

7. How to organize your itinerary

8. What is a deal memo and how it should look like

9. How to organize yourself to get it done as fast and painless as possible

We will dedicate the last half and hour for Q&A so you get clear about all your concerns and questions about this process.

Maximum of 7 people per course.

The first 1 hour info session is Free and the cost of the following course is $250 per person.

You will leave with an action plan under your arm and vast knowledge on how to tackle every task of your application process. You will also have access to an archive of samples of letters of recommendation, deal memo, itineraries and other useful sources to make this process easier and build a strong case for your O1 visa application.

Join us for this Meetup! You will get very valuable information and you will get to meet people to support you along the process.

Special discounts: You can get a 10% if you pay before the day of the course (message us for paying details). Also, if you bring a friend to the course, you get 10% discount for you and 10% for your friend. Also, you organize a group of 5 people and you get the course for FREE!

Can't make it to this date? We teach this course every other Saturday and we also provide one-on-one courses in New York and Online. Visit our website for more details.
results.name: O1 Visa: Working Visa for Artists and Creative Professionals Course in Brooklyn

results.description:
A Women’s Circle & Playshop. 

Come immerse yourself in this juicy expressive-arts process within a circle of warm & like-minded women!

Take this afternoon to connect with your creative self in a warm, supportive environment of other like-minded women. Come immerse yourself in this juicy expressive arts process!

No need for any artistic ability. Just come with an open mind and an open heart!

We will be using the vehicle of SoulCollage® which allows you move past your linear rational mind and step through the doorway into your own deep guidance….. your intuition. This magical process can be used to offer insight into both the big and small decisions in life, clarify solutions to nagging problems, and give you an expressive outlet that is nourishing and joyful.

By using images from magazines, books, and art, you make cards - each collaged card representing one aspect of your personality or Soul. Over time you construct your own deck of unique, soul-tending cards.

You will learn how to interpret the cards and use them intuitively to answer life's questions or explore your inner landscape and reconnect with your deepest wisdom!

All materials are provided! 

No previous training necessary!

During the SoulCollage® Playshop you will receive… 

• Instruction on the SoulCollage® process

• Plenty of card-making time

• Guided card interpretation

• Group sharing

• All card-making materials (you only need to bring a journal if you wish)

• A plethora of sumptuous images for your card-making pleasure

• A lovely folder to take home: lots of handouts and resources, a blank SoulCollage® board and a card-making frame to get you started creating at home 

• PLUS...Cynthia’s personal attention and guidance throughout!

$65 - pre-registration required  -  Invest in your BRILLIANCE!


Cynthia Shaw is is a licensed mental health counselor in private practice for 25 years and has been a SoulCollage® facilitator since 2005. She is also an artist who believes that creativity is as important as breathing. Art and creativity have been Cynthia’s guides to greater self-understanding and wild, luscious fulfillment….. and she LOVES to share that joy with YOU!
results.name: Tapping into your Most Brilliant, Creative Self -         a SoulCollage®Journey

results.description:
Two hour of FREE GIT/GITHUB TRAINING in a really small group setting.  Git is probably one of the most important tools in a developers toolbox, but yet it's not taught in academia.  If you're like me, you strayed away from VCS (version control software) like git because you just didn't GIT IT.  Until one day your yelling at your dev team not to touch a file because your working on it.

There has to be a better way... We call it GIT.

Come join me.. Space is limited because I want participants to have an intimate learning environment.

All levels are welcome.  Save me a couple of minutes and have a github.com account already.  Follow @dboutmybizness @DLynch-Technology
results.how_to_find_us: Ring Bell #3
results.name: Let's Learn: I just don't GIT it! Making sense of git, github, and VCS.

results.description:
Vilhelm Hammershoi (1864 - 1916) was a Danish painter of solitude and light.  His work will remind you of Vermeer, and even Edward Hopper.  24 of his paintings are on view at Scandinavia House.  We're timing this visit to include a 35-minute tour of the exhibit.  The tour is free, but admission is $5.

Sample painting:


Here's a link to the exhibit:   http://www.scandinaviahouse.org/app/uploads/2015/09/Painting-Tranquility-Press-Release-09.22.15.pdf

To get acquainted before the exhibit, we'll meet a few blocks up Park Avenue, at a very special coffee bar & high-end chocolate store called Two Beans.  See link to their beverage menu.  They usually have some light snacks available, such as yogurt or pastries.  You'll want to wander around and browse the chocolate shelves!


http://2beans.com/module/myblogs/pagecontent?post_id=11

After getting acquainted, we'll walk 3 blocks to Scandinavia House.

When the tour ends, you can check out the Scandinavian design shop and the Scandinavian packaged food stand in the lobby.


If something comes up and you can't attend, please change your RSVP status as soon as possible.  Given the small size of this meetup group, no-show's would be a big loss.
results.how_to_find_us: I'll have a red folder and Meetup sign.  Look for me either at the ground level coffee bar, or at a table upstairs
results.name: See Paintings by Vilhelm Hammershoi--"The Danish Vermeer"--at Scandinavia House

results.description:
Discussion is an exchange of knowledge; argument is an exchange of ignorance. 
                                           – Robert Quillen

If you’re reading this description, then you are probably someone who likes having discussions/debates with others on many topics. The meaning of life, the purposes of religion, the nature of love, the ways we deceive ourselves, the pros and cons of pursuing happiness—these may be some of the topics in some of the discussion forums on Meetup that you’ve attended recently.


How much have you thought about why you attend these discussion forums? What do you want to get out of the discussions you participate in? Do you want to see how others see the world? How others see the world differently from you? Do you want to be enlightened? Do you want to have your paradigms penetrated and put to the test in new and interesting ways? 

We will devote one afternoon to discussing discussions!

Our goals will be to consider how the process of discussing important topics with others can challenge the way we see ourselves and those around us, how it can deepen and nuance our current understandings, how it can significantly change our paradigms, and how it can make our lives more meaningful. 

We can even discuss and debate the veracity of the quote above!

About the Moderator:
Rolando is a moderator for Socrates Café. He has moderated discussions on whether the processes of reasoning can lead to truth, how we deceive ourselves and when and if we can counteract these tendencies, how thinking can lead to self-understanding, and other discussions. He spends his spare time cogitating on how conversing with others constructs his paradigms of reality. . .
results.how_to_find_us: 2nd Floor in the back of the deli.  Walk up the stairs.
results.name: How Might Discussions Affect How We See Ourselves & the World? Host: Rolando

results.description:
Discussion is an exchange of knowledge; argument is an exchange of ignorance. 
                                           – Robert Quillen


If you’re reading this description, then you are probably someone who likes having discussions/debates with others on many topics. The meaning of life, the purposes of religion, the nature of love, the ways we deceive ourselves, the pros and cons of pursuing happiness—these may be some of the topics in some of the discussion forums on Meetup that you’ve attended recently.


How much have you thought about why you attend these discussion forums? What do you want to get out of the discussions you participate in? Do you want to see how others see the world? How others see the world differently from you? Do you want to be enlightened? Do you want to have your paradigms penetrated and put to the test in new and interesting ways? 

We will devote one afternoon to discussing discussions!

Our goals will be to consider how the process of discussing important topics with others can challenge the way we see ourselves and those around us, how it can deepen and nuance our current understandings, how it can significantly change our paradigms, and how it can make our lives more meaningful. 

We can even discuss and debate the veracity of the quote above!

He spends his spare time cogitating on how conversing with others constructs his paradigms of reality. . .

This is a co-ed adult pick-up game 6v6 or 7 v7 depending on attendance. 90 minutes with two 45 minute halves. No slide tackling or rough play. We play with Pugg goals. Pinnies provided.  Shin guards are recommended.


This pick up game is hosted by Coach Moe and is free for those who attended both training sessions with him the same day, $4 for all others.


PLEASE UPDATE YOUR RSVP AT LEAST 2 HOURS BEFORE THE GAME!

• Update your RSVP by 11:30AM

• RSVPs close by 12 NOON

• No shows and those who didn't update their RSVP at least 2 hours before the game will be red carded after the second offense, which means that we have the right to edit your RSVP.

Directions by subway or bus:

2 and 3 trains to Clark St.

A and C trains to High St.


F train to York St.


N and R trains to Court St.


Weather policy:

In case of inclement weather we will send out an email to notify you at least two hours before meeting time.

What to bring:

Please note that Cadman Plaza park is a turf field. Turf shoes are preferred. Please bring water or sports drink. Please bring a ball if you have one.

results.description:
Come out for this rare screening of Roeg's "Performance."

Special Film Society Discount—tickets just $11! To redeem: Select the affiliate option from the ticket menu when purchasing online or mention "Art is Culture" at the Walter Reade Theater box office.

—————


The manic, disjunctive editing rhythms that distinguish this devilish late-’60s psychological drama shocked viewers in 1970 nearly as much as did the film’s subject: the strange, tense cohabitation of a London gangster (James Fox) with a self-medicating pop star (Mick Jagger) and his two steady female companions (Anita Pallenberg and Michele Breton). The montage is Nicolas Roeg’s, as were most of the movie’s delirious visual touches, but Performance—one of cinema’s seminal cult classics—was above all the brainchild of Donald Cammell, a major figure in the London underground scene. With its fractured narrative logic and polymorphous sexual dynamics, the film would become a key reference point for glam movies as early as Roeg’s own The Man Who Fell to Earth and as late as Haynes’s Velvet Goldmine.

results.description:
Come join us to speak openly about our faith in our Lord and God Jesus Christ. Let us all be willing to reason and come to an agreement with what is written in the Scriptures. We want to continue in the apostles' doctrine, in fellowship, in breaking of bread, and in prayers.


In 2 Thessalonians 3:1, the apostle Paul exhorted the brethren to pray so that the word of Lord may have free course, and be glorified. Let us also pray so that we can have the same liberty. Let us learn to speak by comparing spiritual things with spiritual, line upon line, precept upon precept.


I am looking forwards to speaking with you and knowing what is the abundance of your heart. Like the apostle Paul, we are willing not to impart the gospel of Jesus Christ only, but also our own souls, because the brethren are dear to us.

results.description:
Last pickup at Pier 5 of the season...


10v10, 75min+ game. Arrive early to warm up, and be ready to start at 2:00pm.


ALL players need to bring a white and black t-shirt and  ball.


It's a large field and some players may need the option to sub. If you're a dedicated goalkeeper let us know - Intermediate level.


****************************************************************

DETAILS:

• Played in a friendly environment. Pass the ball have fun.

• No rough tackles or play. Players are expected to bring a positive attitude, no screaming at/or berating team mates.

•  BRING A BALL. If you hit a ball into the river, you'll need to replace it!  If there aren't any dedicated goalkeepers playing, we rotate in goal every 5 mins.

• No metal cleats. Only turf or molded cleats.

• If you arrive late, pls wait until a break in the game. Inserting players in the middle of the game disrupts the flow, and it's not fair to those that arrive on time.


Payment goes toward field permit, equipment and fees.

See you at the pitch!


Note: The is a 2/3 regulation size field with full size goals. Not suitable for beginner level or inexperienced players.

By joining this group and attending events you agree to the Waiver Of Liability.
results.name: Saturday 10v10 @2:00pm Pier 5, Brooklyn | 75min+ Full Size Goals

results.description:
Free and open to the public. This event repeats every Saturday between 2/14/2015 and 2/27/2016 from 2:00 p.m. to 3:30 p.m.

The Union Square Partnership teamed with Big Onion Walking Tours to create a free, 90-minute walking tour Saturdays entitled Union Square: Crossroads of New York. The tour departs from the Abraham Lincoln Statue located along the 16th Street transverse. With the help of a tour guide, you will explore the social and political history of the Union Square neighborhood through discussions of the people, history, architecture, and forces that have shaped this community. Reservations are not required for individuals, but are required for groups.
results.how_to_find_us: There is no organizer for this - just show up and enjoy the tour.
results.name: Union Square: Crossroads of New York Walking Tour

results.description:
Basic Ground Rules for Participation

Please wear either a blue/black or white shirt to make things easy (Preferably bring both in case we need to mix the teams more evenly).


no need to respond at all if you can't/don't want to play

• if you do respond IN, please come unless something really urgent comes up (hangovers or better offers from your cooler friends not accepted for absences!)


• If you suck at Ultimate... you are more than welcome. This is open to ALL skill levels, ages etc. If you're really good, please pretend you suck every once in a while for the benefit of the rest of us! We're just here to run around and have fun. We all want to score and win but if you want to win at all costs, this is not the game for you.

• The trick with this group is making sure we have enough to play, so those who do show up don't waste a trip, so please make the effort this year to be honest with yourself and us about if you can/want to come down so we can make the right call for GAME ON or GAME OFF. If you are a "maybe" please indicate that via the comment section with a brief explanation (ie 80% chance I'll be there...). If you RSVP and are then unable to attend, please update your RSVP as soon as possible.

What is Ultimate Frisbee? In a nutshell <borrowed from Wiki> :

Ultimate is a limited-contact team field sport played with a disc (frisbee). Points are scored by passing the disc to a teammate in the opposing end zone. Other basic rules are that players must not take steps while holding the disc (maintain a pivot), and interceptions and incomplete passes are turnovers.

Closest analogy I could come up with = a mix of basketball and football, but played with a frisbee. You do not need to be an expert frisbee player/thrower etc. - it's all about having fun.
results.name: NEW TIME - Saturday Ultimate Frisbee (Anderson Park)

results.description:
Meet on the american football field (near the entrance close to the public restrooms)!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 2:00. We typically start 15 minutes after 2:00. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.

results.description:
This Event: 

The aim of this weekly event is to offer a place where Python developers and learners can come and ask questions or give help. 

Individuals of all programming skill levels are welcome. 

It is suggested that you bring your own laptop. If you don't have access to a laptop and want to attend, please let Paul Logston know and he will see about getting you a laptop for the day.

This event is free. 

This event is not a tutorial. Tutorials hosted by Learn Python NYC are labeled as tutorials.

Resources:

Here are some learning resources and free text editor / IDE suggestions.

https://github.com/logston/NYCPythonSOH/blob/master/resources.rst 

Detailed Directions to us:

As you enter the building located at 568 Broadway, New York, NY 10012 you will need to provide ID and your destination (Fueled Collective, 11th Floor) to the front desk. They will provide you with a sticker badge. Take one of the elevators (located to the right of the front desk) to the 11th floor. We will be in the Deerbrook conference room.
results.how_to_find_us: Show ID at front desk, come up to 11th floor, we are in the Deerbrook conference room!
results.name: Saturday Python Study Group

results.description:
Our typical agenda: - We orient new visitors and then chat a bit, as by sharing what's new or good in our lives. - Then we chant and meditate together, together with the beautiful sounds of a gong - And finally we share thoughts and questions, learning something new sometimes, generally supporting each other best we can at all times.

Note that we meet every Wednesday, 7:30 to 9 pm, and every Saturday, 2 to 3:30 pm on Midchester Ave. -- except for the first Saturday of the month, when we meet elsewhere and begin our meeting at 5 pm, followed by an informal potluck social starting about 7 pm.

(When you plan on staying for the potluck, see the log-in information posted at our monthly potluck page. That helps us get healthy, balanced meals.)

By the way, the meetup page may show only a few members planning to attend a particular meeting. That's because many people attend regularly and don't bother to RSVP for each meeting.  We never have only a few members at a meeting. Twenty members more usually attend each meeting.

Call Merrill or Mataji anytime you have questions:[masked]-5334.
results.name: American Meditation Society - Weekly Saturday Meetup in White Plains

results.description:
For details and tickets: https://goo.gl/czxPUl

Prepare for an hour of insane fun, team building, and laughter - as you are about to be trapped in a room with a zombie! (Please arrive 10-15min early. You will spend 60 min in room, with a 10 minute wrap up afterward. So budget 80-90 minutes!)

You and 11 other adventurers will enter a room and are challenged to find the clues, solve the riddles, and get the key to escape.... or get eaten. As the clock dwindles down from 60 to 0, every 5 minutes the hungry zombie's chain gets longer and the danger zone increases. Communication and teamwork are musts if you want to make it out alive.

The event concludes with a comedically insightful analysis of the group's dynamics and of individuals' contributions.

We ask that you please order tickets for a show time at least 8 HOURS PRIOR to that show time.
results.name: Trapped In a Room with a ZOMBIE - Room Escape Adventures!

results.description:
We're bringing back our popular format this month here at BFTVC: All Full Court Evening. We'll have 3 teams of 7, with two subs, and rotate the teams around to play full court games all evening.

And as usual:

We rent out the gym from 5:00-8:00pm. 

Please arrive at least 5-10 minutes early as the sooner everyone arrives, the sooner we can begin playing. Note that all games stop at 7:45pm as we have to be out of the gym by 8:00pm. (If you get there late, please only ring the bell once. It is very loud! And it takes us a few minutes to get downstairs.) The gym is on the 10th fl. & has adjoining bathrooms, lockers, and water fountains.

We'll hit up McSwiggans (393 2nd Avenue @ 23rd St) later! 

Don't forget:

* You must be no more than 5'8" to play!

* You must RSVP on the site in order to attend!

* You will be asked to sign a waiver for 2014 as we're not a litigious group. 

If you have any problems with the prepay, just shoot one of the organizers an email.

Here are the basic rules we follow for games:

1. Play by ones and twos to 11 - win by one point.

2. Walls, and ceiling are out of bounds. 


3. Backcourt if the ball hits the rim or backboard. Air balls are fair game to put right back up.

4. Jump balls/disputed calls will be determined by a three pointer since the laws of basketball physics are very clear that "the ball never lies."

6. Subs will enter the game no later than 6 points in (once one of the teams reaches 6 points). The sub will start the following game. Teams will regulate themselves but let's make sure everyone plays.

See you on the court! B-)

***NOTE***

In an effort for us to reduce overcrowding and to maintain a more accurate estimate of how many people to expect, please sign up online if you intend to play. There is a waiting list if all spots have been taken. We ask that you please just do not show up unannounced as you will kindly be asked to turned away. 

Also feel free to bring your own basketball for shoot-around. And don't forget to clip your nails prior to game day. We tried playing with Edward Scissorhands once - it didn't turn out so well.

results.description:
>>> RSVPs may be closed, but you can still join us by showing up at the door! <<<<<

Every year that our fandom has continued is another year for celebration! The mission of Bronies-NYC is to celebrate our unique culture that has inspired so many around the world and we could think of no better way than a beautiful meal together with our best friends!

Thanksgiving is the holiday where we don't give gifts, don't send cards, don't set off fireworks or go on hikes. 

We gather with our families, enjoy delicious food, experience the joy of being together and share in the gratitude of being in each other's lives. 

That being said we are planning to start a new tradition and serve a beautiful seasonal feast that delights the senses! Before our sumptuous meal we will be screening the SEASON FIVE FINALE! 

From there we will move to the beautifully decorated table where the chefs at Bronies-NYC will serve a turkey dinner with cider and pot-luck trimmings followed by coffee, tea and dessert.


After dinner, join us for a screening (and sing-along!) of DR. HORRIBLE'S SING-ALONG BLOG followed by play through of A PONY KIND OF CHRISTMAS to get us all in the winter spirit.

To pull off this amazing dinner we need everypony's help. Please bring a thanksgiving dinner item to share with all of us. We are looking for vegetable sides, pies, or especially any favourite family recipes.

We are going to serve sliced turkey, cranberry sauce and gravy as an entree, provide a glass of sparkling cider, and serve a soft drink in addition to coffee and tea after dinner. We are also providing place settings and silverware.

To keep our pot-luck organized, please look at our Google Sheet at https://goo.gl/cxle1z to add what you would like to contribute.It is strongly suggested that you bring a dish to share, but we do understand that not everyone can manage it this year.  

***Ticket price***
The cost for this dinner and screening is $20. We are no longer accepting PayPal, but we will be accepting credit and debit cards at the door in addition to cash.

***Vendors***
We have decided to ask our vendors this month to leave the wares at home and enjoy dinner with us all. (we also need every table we can get our hoof on!) In other words, no vending this month.

***Volunteers***
We need a bunch of help to make this meetup run beautifully! Due to the expense of this particular meetup, we are unable to comp our volunteers or organizers, but don't worry, your service will be worth it!  ❀◕ ‿ ◕❀
Sign up here: http://goo.gl/RTc9lP 

Pony Gratitude to all! /)*(\

Join other writers for an hour of focused writing!

5:15 - Get down to business. An hour of silence and solid writing!

If you're spending too much time THINKING about writing, come and join us for a session of focused writing. No one will see what you've written or give you unsolicited advice.

WHERE: Milk and Honey Cafe located at 1119 Newkirk Ave. The closest train station is Newkirk Plaza on the Q line. Walk 3 block down Newkirk Avenue until you reach Westminster Road. We are sitting at the table in the back.

SOME TIPS:

Laptops are welcome. Remember to charge your laptop ahead of time.

Please buy something to support this organic cafe. It would make the owner smile.

Come on time! If you come late, we will have already started.
Bring headphones if you don't want outside noise distraction.

RSVP only if you can make it, and update as soon as possible if your plans change.

You will see progress in your writing project by spending the minimum of a single hour per week on it. This is your practice/focus time, so I hope to see you there.

results.description:
During weekly meetings on Saturday evenings in the East Village of New York City, Atmanivedana das (Atma) and Subhangada devi dasi (Subhie) teach how to hear and chant sanskrit names for God in kirtan and teach a systematic study the Bhagavad-gita As It Is.  Kirtan meditation consists of hearing and chanting sanksrit names for God to the accompaniment of melodious and rhythmic music in order to invoke God's divine mercy and presence.  Bhagavad-gita As It Is is studied according to the ancient, yet unbroken, chain of teachers, as taught originally by Krishna and eventually Sri Caitanya Mahaprabhu, Rupa Goswami, and more recently A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada, the Founder-Acarya of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness.   

Our focus is a systematic and thematic, but not difficult to understand, study of the Bhagavad-gita As It Is.  Everyone will read verses together from the Bhagavad-gita, copies of which will be provided for attendees to reference during the meetup.  Atma and Subhie will together explain the Bhagavad-gita verses according to the ancient tradition that they have studied and lived by for almost fifty years, combined.  We will learn about various fascinating topics, such as karma, reincarnation, the soul, the material energy, the Supreme Soul, time, and the relationship between the soul, the material energy, and the Supreme Soul.

Hard cover copies of the beautiful Bhagavad-gita As It Is with the original 700 sanskrit verses, translations, and elaborate purports by A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada, will be available for any member who might choose to take one home for a suggested donation of $10.

This meetup is intended for everyone who is interested without discrimination and regardless of one's familiarity with the subject matter.  Please come and relish this most wonderful discussion and kirtan, celebrating the glories of bhakti yoga, i.e., devotional service to God, who is known according to the Bhagavad-gita by the name Krishna.

Here is the general schedule of our meetups: we begin the evening with a kirtan that lasts about half an hour -- until about 6:00 p.m.  Then, we have a class on Bhagavad-gita As It Is, which lasts for about an hour and a half.  In the class, we will go through verses of the Gita in order, continuing from where the last class left off, with questions pertaining to those verses being encouraged throughout the class.  By about 7:30, the last kirtan begins; it lasts for about 30 minutes.  A sumptuous and nutritious vegetarian dinner is served after that.

Admission to each meetup is free.  Donations for the meetup's expenses are welcome, but not at all required!

Atma is an initiated priest who since 1990 has been studying, teaching, and living according to the teachings of the Bhagavad-gita as taught and followed by A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada. After living in a monastic setting for eight years, Atma resumed his undergraduate education at Brown University, where he hosted weekly programs that focused on kirtan and Bhagavad-gita.  He then enrolled at the University of Chicago Law School from which he graduated in 2004 and from which he received a merit scholarship.  Atma practices law in Long Island and New York City, with his concentration in securities law.  His primary goal is to imbibe in his own life the devotional teachings of the Bhagavad-gita and to share the same with others as a humble offering to God.

Subhie has been living her life according to the teachings of the Bhagavad-gita since 1991 and is also an initiated priest.  Subhie lived in a monastic setting until 2005.   From 1991 to 2005, Subhie taught Bhagavad-gita in Croatia, Serbia, Greece, Germany, and United Kingdom.  Subhie spent several years studying Vedic knowledge in India, primarily in the holy town, Vrindavana.  After 2005, Subhie resumed her undergraduate education in religion at the University of London -- and then locally at Queens College, after she moved to New York and married Atma.  Subhie completed her Master's degree in teaching at Queens College and is a school teacher.

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event - EXPECT TO MEET 7 TO 12 MEMBERS OF THE OPPOSITE SEX*), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

Get the full details below.

* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$27- PAY IN ADVANCE ONLY - WE DO NOT ACCEPT PAYMENT AT DOOR

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: https://2015atwysspeeddatingnyc.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
Come on out to BushBaby for a Steppin' Lesson and Dance Set post-Thanksgiving with the New York Steppers.  Bushbaby has a great menu, bar, and atmosphere for an early evening steppers set on Saturday night.

We'll be celebrating the birthday of Willena Nanton!


BushBaby  


1197 Fulton Street (A,C trains to Franklin or Nostrand Aves) 
Brooklyn, NY 11216

Time: 6-10pm

Chi Steppin' Lessons: 6-7pm ($10); 

Open Dance: 7-10pm; FREE w/ lesson!; $5 otherwise.

            Beginners are welcome and no partner is necessary!  Make sure you come early for the lesson.  Instructors will be getting their groove on after that! 

           Be sure to save your appetite for dinner and drinks.  Bushbaby has an excellent southern and vegetarian menu and bar!

See you on Saturday night!

*Special: Click RSVP so we begin to reflect actual attendance, and we will enter you each time for a drawing of a Free volume of our Steppers Music CDs and/or Free Class/Admission!
results.name: The BK STEPPERS SET at Bushbaby!  Willena's Birthday
